content: quote: Amid increasing suggestions that Israel might attack Iran’s nuclear facilities, Defense Secretary Robert M. Gates warned that such a strike would have dangerous consequences and asserted that Tehran’s acquisition of a bomb could be prevented only if “Iranians themselves decide it’s too costly.” Using his strongest language on the subject to date, Gates told a group of Marine Corps students that a strike would probably delay Tehran’s nuclear program from one to three years. The attack, however, would unify Iran, “cement their determination to have a nuclear program and also build into the whole country an undying hatred of whoever hits them,” Gates said. (Los Angeles Times, April 16, 2009) "None are more hopelessly enslaved than those who falsely believe they are free." -Johann Wolfgang von Goethe
quote: Amid increasing suggestions that Israel might attack Iran’s nuclear facilities, Defense Secretary Robert M. Gates warned that such a strike would have dangerous consequences and asserted that Tehran’s acquisition of a bomb could be prevented only if “Iranians themselves decide it’s too costly.” Using his strongest language on the subject to date, Gates told a group of Marine Corps students that a strike would probably delay Tehran’s nuclear program from one to three years. The attack, however, would unify Iran, “cement their determination to have a nuclear program and also build into the whole country an undying hatred of whoever hits them,” Gates said. (Los Angeles Times, April 16, 2009)
reply: "None are more hopelessly enslaved than those who falsely believe they are free." -Johann Wolfgang von Goethe

content: I really thought that when it was proven that Iranians killed American service members, W would have done something about it. But as always his priorities had a twisted urgency, one that only leads me to believe there was much more behind Iraq than WMD. Why people defend that type of behavior and glorify him is beyond me. I can overlook mistakes, but not defended our troops in Iraq, no matter the cost was no mistake. We should have bombed the hell out of Iran once we offered the world indisputable proof. That, if any thing showed our true weakness, afraid to put a lid on the pot, when it was already stirred.

content: quote: Amid increasing suggestions that Israel might attack Iran’s nuclear facilities, Defense Secretary Robert M. Gates warned that such a strike would have dangerous consequences and asserted that Tehran’s acquisition of a bomb could be prevented only if “Iranians themselves decide it’s too costly.” Using his strongest language on the subject to date, Gates told a group of Marine Corps students that a strike would probably delay Tehran’s nuclear program from one to three years. The attack, however, would unify Iran, “cement their determination to have a nuclear program and also build into the whole country an undying hatred of whoever hits them,” Gates said. (Los Angeles Times, April 16, 2009) "None are more hopelessly enslaved than those who falsely believe they are free." -Johann Wolfgang von Goethe

The attack, however, would unify Iran, “cement their determination to have a nuclear program and also build into the whole country an undying hatred of whoever hits them,” Gates said. (Los Angeles Times, April 16, 2009)

That, if any thing showed our true weakness, afraid to put a lid on the pot, when it was already stirred.

content: I really thought that when it was proven that Iranians killed American service members, W would have done something about it. But as always his priorities had a twisted urgency, one that only leads me to believe there was much more behind Iraq than WMD. Why people defend that type of behavior and glorify him is beyond me. I can overlook mistakes, but not defended our troops in Iraq, no matter the cost was no mistake. We should have bombed the hell out of Iran once we offered the world indisputable proof. That, if any thing showed our true weakness, afraid to put a lid on the pot, when it was already stirred.
